Name: Is there a distinct category of dual for verbal agreement with a dual subject?
Is non-agreement in number between the nominal subject and verbal predicate possible?
Comment: Only quantity phrases with a noun in the genitive singular or essive do not agree with verbal predicates.

Name: Can finite verbs agree in number with a nominal object?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in case?
Is there non-agreement between an adnominal property word and the head noun?
Comment: Demonstrative pronouns do not agree in terms of case in the adnominal position when a noun is marked with a case other than comitative singular (but not plural), genitive, or nominative. Numerals from 'one' to 'six' demonstrate similar behavior. Demonstrative pronouns and numerals are marked with genetive, however, this form can be analyzed as an underspecified oblique form as well.

Name: Can adpositions be used to mark core verbal arguments?
Can non-finite clauses use a special means for core argument (S/A) marking?
Comment: Non-finites require marking an S/A-argument with genitive or comitative.

Name: Can non-finite clauses use a special means for core argument (P) marking?
Do the characteristics of the object referent (topicality, animacy, definiteness) influence object marking?
Does object marking correlate with aspectuality?
Does object marking depend on the verb conjugation form?
Is there differential subject marking?
Can S and A be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e., act as a syntactic pivot?
Can S and P be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e., act as a syntactic pivot?
Is there grammatical marking of habituality?
Comment: Habitual and frequentative meanings are marked with the same derivational suffix.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of frequentativity?
Comment: Habitual and frequentative meanings are marked with the same derivational suffix.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of progressivity?
Is it common to use a verb in the present tense for future time reference?
Comment: Telic verbs in the present tense refer to the future. However, atelic verbs in the present tense can only refer to the future in the context of planned activities.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of the immediate future?
Comment: An inchoative marker can have prospective meaning only in some idiolects.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of the pluperfect?
Can aspect be expressed overtly in the negative marker?
Can tense be expressed overtly in the negative marker?
Is there grammatical marking of mirativity?
Comment: Perfect can sometimes have a mirative reading.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of a desire or wish?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to irrealis?
Are verbs marked with a non-indicative mood in counterfactual conditional clauses?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic necessity?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of epistemic possibility?
Comment: Epistemic possibility was encoded with potential mood in archaic language.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic possibility?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to direct commands/wishes, etc. to the 3Sg?
Comment: There were jussive forms in archaic language.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb used to direct commands/wishes, etc. to the 1Sg?
Is it common to use the imperative/jussive in complement clauses introduced by predicates expressing wish/desire/will?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of apprehension?
Is there a reflexive conjugation?
Can non-singular 2nd and 3rd person have the same person/number marking or morphosyntactic treatment?
Can the 3rd person plural verb form and impersonal (passive) verb form be encoded in the same way?
Are 2nd person singular verb forms commonly used with a generic meaning?
Can an infinitival verb form be used in a directive function?
Can verbs in purposive subordinate clauses be bare infinitive forms?
Are there sentences without overt verbal arguments?
Is a copula commonly used for predicate nominals in the 3rd person singular forms of the present tense?
Is a copula commonly used for predicate nominals in the past tense?
Can locative constructions commonly occur without a copula?
Is the same coordinating conjunction commonly used for NPs, VPs, and clauses?
Does existential negation have a special negator?
Can standard negation be asymmetric in the present tense?
Can non-finite dependent clauses use the standard negation construction?
Is there a special negator that combines with non-finite forms?
Are there special negative non-finite forms?
Is there an impersonal passive construction?
Are there non-finite forms specializing in the relativization of particular core participants, e.g., subjects (S/A), direct objects (P), absolutive participants (S/P)?
Are there non-finite forms that can relativize all core participants (S/A/P) and possibly also some non-core participants?
Comment: When used adnominally, the non-finite form on -əm <-эм> relativizes mostly non-core participants, however, occasionally it can relativize subject and object as well.

Name: Are there non-finite forms that can relativize at least some non-core participants but cannot relativize all core participants?
Is there a specialized negative participial form, which cannot be analyzed as a specific participial marker + negative marker?
Is there a future participle?
Are there participles that can encode their subject with possessive suffixes?
Are there participles that must agree with the nouns they modify in case and number in all contexts?
Are there non-finite forms that can be used both as participles and action nominalizations?
Are there non-finite forms that can be used both as participles and agentive nominalizations?
Are there non-finite forms that can be used both as participles and converbs?
Is OV the neutral order in affirmative imperative clauses?
Is it possible to place an object between the negative marker and the main verb in imperative constructions?
Is there diminutive (hypocoristic) marking on verbs?
Can modifiers of action nominalizations in agent and patient roles both be encoded like possessors?
Can the modifier of action nominalizations in the patient role be encoded like a direct object?
Do core adjectives agree with the subject noun in number in the predicative position?
Comment: The agreement of adjectives in number has almost been lost in modern language.

Name: Is there a bound superlative degree marker on property words?
Can adpositions have person/number marking?
Comment: The only adposition allowing a person marker is mʲiːlʲːtʲe 'along, behind, with'. However, person marking in this adposition has almost been lost in modern language.

Name: Are there adpositions that show a tripartite system?
Is there case compounding?
Are there morphological cases only used with pronouns?
Does the numeral modification of a noun have an effect on its case selection?
Is the singular form of the noun also used with numerals greater than 1?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses indirect object/recipient/goal (different from a local case)?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses a terminative meaning?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses the absence of a referent (abessive)?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses motion along or by a referent (prolative)?
Is there a locative case that expresses goal?
Is there a locative case that expresses location?
Is there a locative case that expresses source?
Is there case syncretism for goal and location marking?
Is there case syncretism for location and source marking?
Are there two sets of local cases?
Are there three or more sets of local cases?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses the means by which something is carried out (instrumental) and/or accompaniment (comitative)?
Is there a case that expresses the means by which something is carried out (instrumental), which is different from a case that expresses accompaniment (comitative) or other relations?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses the result of a change of state (translative) and/or a state of being (essive)?
Is there a case that expresses a state of being (essive), which is different from a case that expresses the result of a change of state (translative) or other relations?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses equativity?
Is there an inflectional nominal marker for expressing benefactive or destinative semantics independent from the dative?
Is there (in addition to the basic declension) a declension different from a possessive declension?
Is it possible to use the singular with the paired body parts/clothing/accessories that accompany them?
Can the marking of the possessor in the attributive construction vary?
Comment: Only genetive marking is possible in attributive constructions. External and predicative possessors require locative.

Name: Can the possessor in the attributive construction be encoded with the nominative?
Are singular and plural possessee distinguished in the possessive declension?
Can a 2Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Can a 3Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Is there a human vs. non-human distinction in independent interrogative pronouns?
Does 'who' commonly appear as a relative pronoun used for animates other than humans?
Does 'who' commonly appear as a relative pronoun used for inanimates?
Comment: The use of mʲiː 'what' and kuː 'which' is more common, but kʲeː 'who' can sometimes still be used for inanimate objects as well.

Name: Can a demonstrative stem be used as a pronoun with a 3Sg human referent?
Are there possessive suffixes, the position of which varies in relation to case/number suffixes?
Are case and number marked cumulatively across the paradigm?
Comment: Number and case are marked comulatively within a case-number marker.

Name: Are there different words for mother’s brother and father’s brother?
Are there different words for younger and older relatives for relations other than siblings?
Is there an animacy distinction for both concepts: 'new/young' and 'old'?
Comment: There is a strict animacy distinction for the concepts 'new' and 'young'. For the concept 'old', there is a syncretic term wuəmʲː 'old (animate/inanimate)' alongside a specialized term puərʲesʲ 'old (animate); elder'.

Name: Is there a distinction for both 'warm' and 'cold' depending on whether reference is to weather or the temperature of objects?
Comment: There is the distinction only for 'warm':pɒːhk ‘warm (of the atmosphere)’ vs lʸiːŋʸgʸ-esʸ ‘warm (of the liquids)’.

Name: Is there contrastive length for consonants?
Is there contrastive length for vowels?
Is there a contrast between short and long unstressed vowels?
Is there a contrast in the length of geminate consonants?
Are there more than two phonological quantities?
Are there extralong syllables?
Is the main foot structure trochaic?
Comment: Trisyllabic dactyl feet are also possible.

Name: Is there lexically distinctive word stress?
Is there morphologically conditioned stress?
Comment: The comitative plural and inchoative markers require secondary stress, otherwise three or four syllabic forms do not obligatory have a secondary stress on the third syllable.

Name: Is there fixed primary stress?
Is there stress in heavy syllables?
Is there non-initial primary stress?
Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Is there velar vowel harmony?
Is there labial vowel harmony?
Are there closing diphthongs?
Are there opening diphthongs?
Comment: There are two lowering diphthongs:<уэ> /uə/ and <уа> /oa/  traditionally analyzed as /ua/. Some descriptions (e.g. Rießler 2022) analyze <е̄> and <я̄> as /ie/ and /ea/ respectively. In the modern language, /ie/ and /ea/ became monophthongs. Coarticulations triggered by palatalization can cause a diphthong-like effect.

Name: Is there a qualitative contrast between subsets of short and long vowels?
Are there full vs. reduced vowels as contrastive subsets?
Is there a high front rounded vowel /y/?
Is there a mid-high front rounded vowel /ø/?
Is there a high back unrounded vowel /ɯ ɨ/?
Is there a mid-high back unrounded vowel /ɤ ɘ/?
Is there a low back rounded vowel /ɒ/?
Is there a contrast between mid front vowels (/e/ or /ɛ/) and low front vowels (/æ/ or /a/)?
Are there word-initial consonant clusters?
Comment: Word-initial consonant clusters are restricted to recent Russian loanwords.

Name: Are there word-internal consonant clusters in the syllable onset?
Are there consonant clusters in the syllable coda?
Are there word-internal intervocalic clusters of three or more consonants?
Are there word-final clusters of three or more consonants?
Are there palatalized alveolar consonants?
Are there palatalized labial and velar consonants?
Is there a palatal stop?
Is there a palatal nasal /ɲ/?
Is there a palatal lateral /ʎ/?
Comment: There was palatal [ʎ] opposed to palatalized [lʲ] in more archaic dialects. Nowadays, a cluster /lʲj/ is attested on the place of [ʎ].

Name: Is there a velar nasal /ŋ/?
Is there an alveolar affricate /t͡s/?
Is there a non-alveolar affricate (e.g., /t͡ʃ/, /t͡ɕ/)?
Is there a phonological contrast between an unvoiced alveolar sibilant /s/ and an unvoiced postalveolar sibilant /ʃ/?
Are there voiced plosives (e.g., /b g d/)?
Comment: Word-initial /b/, /d/, /g/ are restricted to functional words and recent borrowings.

Name: Is there a glottal stop /ʔ/?
Is there a phonological contrast between plain and labial velar consonants (e.g., /k/ vs. /kʷ/)?
Is there a constraint on the word-initial alveolar trill /r/?
Is there a laryngeal fricative /h/?
Comment: [h] is analyzed as part of preaspiration occlusives in some descriptions (e.g., Rießler 2022).

Name: Is there a voiced velar fricative /ɣ/?
Comment: [ɣ] is attested in place of the modern word-final and word-medial [g] in more archaic dialects.

Name: Is there a voiceless velar fricative /x/?
Is there a voiced dental fricative /ð/?
Comment: [ð] is attested in place of the modern word-final and word-medial [d] in more archaic dialects.

Name: Is there a labio-velar approximant /w/?
Comment: There is no phonemic opposition /w/ vs /v/. [w] and [v] are in free variation, at least in some positions. It is difficult to determine which label - /w/ or /v/ - is more appropriate for this phoneme.

Name: Is there a voiceless labiodental fricative /f/?
Comment: /f/ is a rare, but absolutely full-fledged phoneme.

Name: Is there radical qualitative consonant gradation?
Is there quantitative consonant gradation?
